results.headline: A Monument Crumbling With All Its Dark Secrets

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Decay of Fiction

results.summary_short: If there were more experimental films as entertaining as this Hollywood ghost story, the notion of a thriving avant-garde cinema might not be so intimidating to the moviegoing public.

results.headline: Floating Above the Slums of Manila on a Current of Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros

results.summary_short: The newcomer Nathan Lopez delights as the flamboyantly gay Maxi, the youngest son in a family of thieves who falls in love with a handsome police officer.

results.headline: It Was Loud. It Was Fast. But What Did It Mean?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Hardcore

results.summary_short: This documentary chronicle of the hardcore punk movement in the first half of the 1980’s imagines an underground culture that was more than a new generation’s style of hormonal eruption.

results.headline: A Journey Through Forests and a Sense of Regret

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Old Joy

results.summary_short: Kelly Reichardt’s film is a triumph of modesty and of seriousness that also happens to be one of the finest American films of the year.

results.headline: A Bedroom Farce With Mortality Hiding in the Closet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Solo Con Tu Pareja

results.summary_short: Like “Y Tu Mamá También,” Alfonso Cuarón’s first feature, made 15 years ago, is a rambunctious sex comedy shadowed by mortality.

results.headline: Complex Side Effects of Poverty

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Home

results.summary_short: Two women reach out to each other from opposite sides of the socioeconomic divide in Jeffrey M. Togman's marvelously revealing documentary about the psychology of poverty.

results.headline: Bad-News Bears? No, Slow-Pitch Sloths

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Artie Lange's Beer League

results.summary_short: Artie Lange, Howard Stern’s radio sidekick, somehow manages to make beer-league softball seem no fun at all in this extremely lowbrow comedy.

results.headline: A Vacation Video From a Forbidden Land

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vajra Sky Over Tibet

results.summary_short: Limited almost exclusively to tourist attractions, this documentary glimpse at the sights and sounds of occupied Tibet amounts to a rhetorically inflated vacation video.

results.headline: The Broken Souls of Men Turned Into War Machines

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ground Truth

results.summary_short: Patricia Foulkrod’s documentary about the war in Iraq stands out as an especially pointed indictment of the American military’s treatment of its own people on and off the battlefield.

results.headline: Mary Poppins’s Dotty Doppelgänger

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Keeping Mum

results.summary_short: This dark British comedy exudes the comfy familiarity of a vintage episode of “Alfred Hitchcock Presents” stretched into a feature-length film.

results.headline: Lennon as Superior to Nixon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The U.S. vs. John Lennon

results.summary_short: Using archival clips and talking-head interviews, this documentary makes the case that John Lennon was a much better person than Richard Nixon.

results.headline: Your Girlfriend Is Pregnant, You’re Wandering Astray, and Worse, 30 Is Near

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Kiss

results.summary_short: Tony Goldwyn’s remake of a popular Italian film is thin and clumsy, but nonetheless unusually candid in its treatment of human sexual misbehavior.

results.headline: A Good Deed for the Sultan of Swat

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everyone's Hero

results.summary_short: Animated in name only, “Everyone’s Hero” follows a 10-year-old baseball fanatic who finds himself in possession of Babe Ruth’s stolen bat.

results.headline: Plots and Personalities Collide on a Tropical Island

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Haven

results.summary_short: Class, race and preposterous narrative contrivance mix it up in the Cayman Islands in this non-linear nonsense from the producer of “Crash.”

results.headline: Seeking Rehabilitation in the End Zone

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gridiron Gang

results.summary_short: Jumping from heartwarming to murderous, this sports-as-rehab movie wants to have its lawlessness and cure it, too.

results.headline: In a Noir Los Angeles, Murder Most Lurid

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Black Dahlia

results.summary_short: Brian De Palma drains the life out of James Ellroy's take on the spectacularly cruel 1947 murder of a young Los Angeles woman known as the Black Dahlia.

results.headline: When the Marital Becomes the Martial

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Confetti

results.summary_short: Anyone who has cringed while watching the home movies of newlyweds bumbling through their own corny, personalized nuptials will appreciate the comic potential of this British mock documentary

results.headline: Family Drama at a Father's Final Curtain Call

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Checking Out

results.summary_short: Based on a 1976 play by Allen Swift, “Checking Out” is stagy, stiff and marinated in egg cream.

results.headline: The Cure for a Cold Heart

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aurora Borealis

results.summary_short: Miserable in Minneapolis, a damaged slacker (Joshua Jackson)finds his life heating up when he connects with the nurse (Juliette Lewis) looking after his grandfather.

results.headline: Comedian Turned Activist, With His Own Campaign

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Al Franken: God Spoke

results.summary_short: The documentary “Al Franken: God Spoke” is perhaps best viewed as an investigation of the phenomenon of ideological celebrity, with Mr. Franken as a willing case study.
